de.larssh.utils.text

Class Strings

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.larssh.utils.text.Strings

  • public final class Strings
extends Object
    This class contains helper methods for String.

        • ...
        • m: -3
        • k: 3
        • M: 6
        • ...

      • DEFAULT_CHARSET

        public static final Charset DEFAULT_CHARSET
        Constant UTF-8 for usage as default char set.

        Using Charset.defaultCharset() leads to unexpected compatibility problems. While the new Files API has been changed to use UTF-8 by default, old and third-party implementations still depend on the default char set or require a custom char set.

        Why shouldn't I use StandardCharsets.UTF_8 directly?
        Using StandardCharsets.UTF_8 is bad practice, as it holds implementation specific information.

      • DEFAULT_LOCALE

        public static final Locale DEFAULT_LOCALE
        Constant locale as default locale where no language and country is required.

        Using Locale.getDefault() leads to unexpected behavior for technical formatting operations. Therefore this locale specifies a default value.

        The returned value is Locale.ROOT.

      • NEW_LINE

        public static final String NEW_LINE
        Constant "\n" for output. Remember to accept "\r\n" and "\r" on the input side, too!

        Using System.lineSeparator() leads to files, which cannot (should not) be transferred between UNIX and Microsoft Windows systems. To avoid problems, some developers decided to depend on the UNIX line separator only.

        Why shouldn't I use "\n" directly?
        Using "\n" is bad practice, as it holds implementation specific information.

    • Method Detail

      • endsWithIgnoreCase

        public static boolean endsWithIgnoreCase(String value,
                                         String suffix)
        Tests if this string ends with the specified suffix, ignoring case considerations.
        Parameters:
        value - string to compare against
        suffix - the suffix.
        Returns:
        true if the character sequence represented by the argument is a suffix of the character sequence represented by this object, ignoring case considerations; false otherwise.

      • find

        public static boolean find(CharSequence input,
                           Pattern pattern)
        Tells whether or not a subsequence input matches pattern.

        Use Patterns.find(Pattern, CharSequence) if you need a matcher.

        Parameters:
        input - the input sequence to find the pattern in
        pattern - the matching pattern
        Returns:
        true if, and only if, input matches pattern

      • format

        public static String format(String format,
                            Object... arguments)
        Returns a formatted string using the specified format string and arguments. In that way this method works similar to String.format(String, Object...).

        Here are the differences:

        • In case arguments is empty, no checks and formatting is performed. format is returned immediately and without modification.
        • DEFAULT_LOCALE is used instead of the systems default Locale.
        • On formatting failure no exception is thrown. When used for error messages this often hides the original error message. Instead a failure message is returned, containing format.
        Parameters:
        format - format string
        arguments - arguments referenced by format specifiers in format
        Returns:
        formatted string

      • isBlank

        public static boolean isBlank(@Nullable
                              CharSequence value)
        Returns true if value consists of whitespace only or equals null.

        This is an optimized way of value.trim().isEmpty().

        Parameters:
        value - string
        Returns:
        true if value consists of whitespace only or equals null

        Use Patterns.matches(Pattern, CharSequence) if you need a matcher.

        Parameters:
        input - the value to match
        pattern - the matching pattern
        Returns:
        true if, and only if, input matches pattern

      • numericTextComparator

        public static Comparator<String> numericTextComparator(boolean caseInsensitive)
        A Comparator that orders alpha numeric strings in natural order, either case sensitive or case insensitive. It is appreciated to use this kind of ordering for user output.

        Because numeric values are not deserialized into numeric data types, their length is not limited. Fractions are not supported and will be handled as two separate numeric values.

        Numeric values can have a leading plus or minus sign when following a whitespace character or at a strings start.

        The following lists some example values to demonstrate the ordering.

        • Banana -12 Circus
        • Banana -5 Circus
        • Banana +5 Circus
        • Banana 5 Circus
        • Banana +5 Dolphin
        • Banana 8 Circus
        • Banana 12 Circus
        • Banana-5 Circus
        • Banana-12 Circus
        • Banana--5 Circus
        • Elephant 5 Circus

        This comparator permits null values.

        Note that this Comparator does not take locale into account, and will result in an unsatisfactory ordering for certain locales.

        Parameters:
        caseInsensitive - true if comparison should take place case insensitive
        Returns:
        a Comparator that orders alpha numeric strings in natural order, either case sensitive or case insensitive. It is appreciated to use this kind of ordering for user output.

      • parseBinaryUnit

        public static BigInteger parseBinaryUnit(String binaryValue)
                                  throws ParseException
        Parses binaryValue as binary value with
        • optional sign,
        • optional fraction
        • and optional binary unit (case insensitive matching).

        Binary units multiply by 1024. Though strings with fractions can be parsed, the resulting value must not contain a fraction part. Numeric values can be formatted using underscore, just as numeric Java literals can be formatted.

        Examples:

        Examples
        Parameter Calculation Return Value
        -2m -2 * 1024 * 1024 -2 097 152
        0 0
        5.4k 5.4 * 1024 5529.6 -> ArithmeticException
        +5_432 5 432
        Parameters:
        binaryValue - binary string
        Returns:
        binary value
        Throws:
        ParseException - on parse failure

      • parseDecimalUnit

        public static BigDecimal parseDecimalUnit(String decimalValue)
                                   throws ParseException
        Parses decimalValue as decimal value with
        • optional sign,
        • optional fraction
        • and optional decimal unit (case insensitive matching - where possible).

        Numeric values can be formatted using underscore, just as numeric Java literals can be formatted.

        Examples:

        Examples
        Parameter Return Value
        -2m -0.002
        0 0
        5.4k 5 400
        +5_432 5 432
        Parameters:
        decimalValue - decimal string
        Returns:
        decimal value
        Throws:
        ParseException - on parse failure

      • replaceFirst

        public static String replaceFirst(CharSequence input,
                                  Pattern pattern,
                                  String replacement)
        Replaces the first subsequence of input that matches pattern with replacement.

        Note that replacement is not a literal replacement string. Backslashes (\) and dollar signs ($) may be treated differently. Quote unknown literal replacement strings using Matcher.quoteReplacement(String).

        Parameters:
        input - the value to match
        pattern - the matching pattern
        replacement - the replacement string
        Returns:
        the string constructed by replacing each matching subsequence by the replacement string, substituting captured subsequences as needed

      • replaceAll

        public static String replaceAll(CharSequence input,
                                Pattern pattern,
                                String replacement)
        Replaces every subsequence of input that matches pattern with replacement.

        Note that replacement is not a literal replacement string. Backslashes (\) and dollar signs ($) may be treated differently. Quote unknown literal replacement strings using Matcher.quoteReplacement(String).

        Parameters:
        input - the value to match
        pattern - the matching pattern
        replacement - the replacement string
        Returns:
        the string constructed by replacing each matching subsequence by the replacement string, substituting captured subsequences as needed

      • startsWithIgnoreCase

        public static boolean startsWithIgnoreCase(String value,
                                           String prefix)
        Tests if this string starts with the specified prefix, ignoring case considerations.
        Parameters:
        value - string to compare against
        prefix - the prefix.
        Returns:
        true if the character sequence represented by the argument is a prefix of the character sequence represented by this string, ignoring case considerations; false otherwise.

      • startsWithIgnoreCase

        public static boolean startsWithIgnoreCase(String value,
                                           String prefix,
                                           int offset)
        Tests if the substring of this string beginning at the specified index starts with the specified prefix, ignoring case considerations.
        Parameters:
        value - string to compare against
        prefix - the prefix.
        offset - where to begin looking in this string.
        Returns:
        true if the character sequence represented by the argument is a prefix of the substring of this object starting at index offset, ignoring case considerations; false otherwise. The result is false if offset is negative or greater than the length of this String object.

      • toNeutralLowerCase

        public static String toNeutralLowerCase(String value)
        Converts all of the characters in value to lower case using DEFAULT_LOCALE. This method is equivalent to toLowerCase(Locale.ROOT).
        Parameters:
        value - string to convert
        Returns:
        converted string

      • toNeutralTitleCase

        public static String toNeutralTitleCase(String value)
        Converts value to title case by converting its first character using Character.toTitleCase(char) and following to lower case using DEFAULT_LOCALE.
        Parameters:
        value - string to convert
        Returns:
        converted string

      • toNeutralUpperCase

        public static String toNeutralUpperCase(String value)
        Converts all of the characters in value to upper case using DEFAULT_LOCALE. This method is equivalent to toUpperCase(Locale.ROOT).
        Parameters:
        value - string to convert
        Returns:
        converted string

      • trimStart

        public static String trimStart(String value)
        Returns a string similar to value, but with any leading whitespace removed.

        This method works similar to String.trim(), though it handles only the strings start.

        Whitespace characters are recognized using Characters.isAsciiWhitespace(char).

        Parameters:
        value - value
        Returns:
        left trimmed value

      • trimEnd

        public static String trimEnd(String value)
        Returns a string similar to value, but with any trailing whitespace removed.

        This method works similar to String.trim(), though it handles only the strings end.

        Whitespace characters are recognized using Characters.isAsciiWhitespace(char).

        Parameters:
        value - value
        Returns:
        left trimmed value
